repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.
did.abstract: Douglas MacKinnon was a radio program director, businessman, and music aficionado. The collection includes materials from MacKinnon's many ventures in music and radio, including his work at Harvard University, his leadership at the WQXR radio station in New York, his service in the U.S. Army during World War II, his work with Radio Free Europe, his writings for Opera News, and numerous other interests and pursuits. Also present are MacKinnon's diaries, datebooks, personal correspondence, and autobiographical writings.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. The library may require up to 48-hours to retrieve these materials for research use.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Copyright Notice
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Douglas MacKinnon Papers were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift in 1987.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Accession(s) described in this collection guide: 1987
Materials may not have been ordered and described beyond their original condition.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Douglas MacKinnon studied music at Harvard University. He was musical founder and director of New York's music station WQXR. As assistant to the National Broadcasting Company's Music Counsel, Dr. Walter Damrosch, he helped produce The Children's Hour, did research for the NBC Symphony, and wrote its scripts. In World War II he was a founder of the Armed Forces Master Records (AFMR) which sent disks of classical music to military bases. In the South Pacific he served with the Office of War Information, broadcasting to troops. He also worked as chief of music production for Radio Free Europe.
Other career ventures later in life included Career Protreptors, a music agency; he also reviewed operas throughout the world for the Metropolitan Opera's magazine, Opera News.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview

controlaccess.subject: World War, 1939-1945 -- Music and the war
Music -- History and criticism

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The bulk of this series consists of MacKinnon's diaries, which range in format from loose typescript pages to small bound manuscript volumes. This series also includes MacKinnon's drafts, research, and notes regarding his autobiography, which he never published.

did.unittitle: Personal Files, Research, and Drafts of Autobiographies
Programs and invitations for performances and life events
Research and correspondence re: funding autobiography

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Box 20 includes loose snapshots of MacKinnon's life, including army service, European travel, his youth and college years, and formal portraits. Many of the photographs do not have captioned and have not been arranged beyond being sleeved for preservation.

did.unittitle: The University Double Quartet, Harvard University

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes programs, advertisements, and other publicity materials from MacKinnon's time as manager of the campus group.

did.unittitle: Documents re: vehicles, transportation during cancer treatment
Programs/ephemera featuring Douglas MacKinnon as performer
Diary: Trip to Spain and Yugoslavia
Le Paquet au Front (address at World Theatre)
Notes and corrections on WQXR article
Work for the Geneva Weekly Tribune
Prisoner in the Congo drafts and article
MacKinnon's notes about Rebel in Radio, by Elliott Sanger, along with DM's copy of the book
Ideas and notes for articles to develop

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes files with MacKinnon's correspondence and collectibles from his relationships with various musicians, public figures, and organizations. Arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Photographs, correspondence (including fan mail), scripts, radio programs, press, employment information, and other miscellaneous materials relating to MacKinnon's work at various radio stations. The majority of the series relates to MacKinnon's work as music director for W2XR and WQXR in New York. The series also contains correspondence, notes, and writings by MacKinnon about his employment (and termination) from WXQR in 1941. Other stations represented include Australian Broadcasting Company and WGHF. There is some overlap between this series and the World War II series. Materials from Radio Free Europe are filed under Postwar Employment.

did.unittitle: WQXR Nothing New to Music scripts
WQXR Nothing New to Music fan mail
WQXR correspondence, claims, disputes over employment
MacKinnon to Arthur Hays Sulzberger re: WQXR

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Transcript, draft, and research for "Lincoln the Man" talk.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes materials from MacKinnon's U.S. Army service during and after World War II. Also includes his work with Armed Forces Master Records, Inc., an organization that distributed music to servicemen.

did.unittitle: AFMR American Broadcasting in Sydney, Australia
AFMR lists of available music and proposed programs
Personal military documents and identification cards

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes issues of The Garble, a 5th AACS comedy newsletter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Box 20 includes loose snapshots of MacKinnon's life, including army service, European travel, his youth and college years, and formal portraits. Many of the photographs do not have captioned and have not been arranged beyond being sleeved for preservation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series includes MacKinnon's incoming and outgoing correspondence to a wide range of professional and personal contacts. Arranged in loose chronological order by five-year increments. The remainder of the collection also has correspondence filed with specific events or periods of MacKinnon's life.

did.unittitle: Christmas/New Year's letters to friends and family
Postcards from MacKinnon to his sister, Mrs. Robert West
Correspondence re: autobiography, with Bernice Rodgers
Correspondence kept by DM for autographs (photocopies)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes materials documenting MacKinnon's work with Investors Overseas Services Management (IOS), Career Protreptors, and his financial and other employment records following his work with the U.S. Army. His work with the Metropolitan Opera is documented in the Musical Events series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence, scripts, schedules, programming suggestions, publicity, and other materials relating to the operation of Radio Free Europe.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Issue numbers 10-12, 14-17, 19-20.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Issue numbers 1-9.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Miscellaneous RFE technical and procedural documents

Radio schedules and programs (all desks: Polish, German, Czech, and Hungarian)

Inaugural broadcast to Hungary: transcript and press

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains itineraries, administrative materials, hotel and travel plans, and programs from MacKinnon's operation of a tour through Europe's music festivals in summer of 1956 and 1957.

did.unittitle: Events and performances in Europe: programs, notes, and reviews
Events and performances in Europe: programs, notes, and reviews

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: MacKinnon worked for IOS while based in Geneva. This subseries documents his work in the financial sector, during which time he traveled widely through Europe attending opera and music performances.

did.unittitle: Inside IOS: 12 Exciting and Agonizing Years, by MacKinnon
Case against DM by Swiss Federal Department of Finance and Customs for smuggling a Chrysler

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: MacKinnon operated Career Protreptors, a music representation agency, for a short period of time. The subseries includes drafts and early documentation of the agency, as well as ephemeral materials from some of his clients.

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous clippings, promotional materials, and notes
Events and performances in Europe: programs, notes, and reviews
Miscellaneous professional endeavors: tour guide, lecturer, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: MacKinnon's notes, programs, ticket stubs, and other ephemera from his travels to various musical events, largely operas in European cities. Files are arranged by location, either city or country, and often include MacKinnon's handwritten notes about particular operas or performances he attended. Some of these files include his drafts for Opera News articles. Some files also include MacKinnon's press copies of opera performances or theaters, usually intended for circulation and labeled with his name.

did.unittitle: Douglas MacKinnon's schedules of European opera performances

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes two folders about the Metropolitan Opera House.
